prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Imaging requirements: We wish to observe a large sample (70 sources) of high-mass young stellar objects in band 6, in order to search for hot molecular core (HMC) emission. We plan to reach an angular resolution of 1 arcsec, achievable with the compact C34-2 configuration. Note that we are not worried about resolving the HMC structure: the typical size of a HMC is <0.1pc (or a few arcsec at distances <3.5 kpc). Thus we will not have problems with structures extending beyond the maximum angular scale (11.4 arcsec) that can be imaged.
Correlator setup: The correlator setup is chosen in such a way to cover a number of good hot core tracers: CH3CN(12-11) ground state and v8=1, 13CH3CN(12-11), HC3N(24-23) and (26-25), as well as different transitions from complex organic molecules: CH3OCHO, CH3OCH3, C2H5CN. We will also cover the 13CO(2-1), SiO(5-4) and some SO lines that will be used as outflow tracers. In total we will use 16 spectral windows with a bandwidth of 234 MHz, and a spectral resolution of 564 kHz (corresponding to 0.7-0.8 km/s). Given the broad line widths observed toward HMCs (typically 5-7 km/s), such a spectral resolution is enough to resolve the line emission.
Requested sensitivity: The expected line intensity for hot core tracers can be estimated from previous single-dish observations (e.g., Araya et al 2005). Considering a source of a few arcsec (<0.1 pc) dilluted in the single-dish beam, we expect these lines to have a brightness temperature of a few K. These estimates coincide with the line intensities mesaured toward intermediate-mass hot cores via detailed interferometer observations (e.g., Palau et al 2011). Thus, we expect these lines to be a few K (or a few hundreds of mJy/beam). Therefore, we plan to reach a sensitivity of 0.25 K (or 10 mJy/beam), which should suffice to detect HMCs with SNR >10.
Science goals: We have created 8 identical science goals in order to group the 70 sources according to their distribution in the sky (i.e., separated by less than 10 degrees). Each science goal contains between 6 and 13 sources. The "spectral setup" and the "control and performance" are identical for all the 8 "science goals".
Time constraints: None
User defined calibrations: None

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Despite recent advances in the characterization of the early stages of massive star-forming regions, many questions remain still open. In particular, questions regarding the earliest phase known to date in the formation of a massive star: the hot molecular core (HMC) - characterized by high temperatures (>100 K) and a rich chemistry. Must all the (massive) protostars undergo the HMC stage? Are the HMCs specifically associated with a dominant star formation phenomena (infall, outflow, ionized gas)? Which is the lifetime of HMCs (there are notable discrepancies between the number of known HMCs and the number predicted by theoretical and chemical models)? Current surveys of dense gas tracers toward large samples of massive young stellar objects, have not followed a good strategy to search for HMCs. We propose to carry out a sensitive, high-energy line survey, to probe the presence of HMCs towards a large sample of massive young stellar objects. By observing reliable hot core tracers we aim: (1) to detect and classify HMCs, and estimate their lifetimes; (2) to determine the relation between HMCs with infall, outflow and ionized gas, as traced by other data available in the literature.
